column1: Reporting rate Road fatalities
For various reasons the police do not register all road traffic crashes and casualties.
Other registers like the Statistics Netherlands Cause of Death Statistics are not complete either.
Each of the data sources has its own ‘blind spots’.
Based on an individual data source it is therefore impossible to obtain a clear picture of the actual numbers of crashes and casualties.
The actual numbers can however be estimated by combining the individual sources.
This may then provide insight into the degree of completeness of each individual data source.
NA
Statistics Netherlands analyses data from three different data sources to determine the number of road deaths in the Netherlands:
Court files on deaths by unnatural causes
Cause of death forms filled out by a coroner
Database of Registered Crashes in the Netherlands (in Dutch: BRON, police crash reports compliled by the Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management (IenW))
We consider this combined data set as complete.
See also our FactSheet Road Deaths
https://swov.nl/en/fact/road-deaths-3-how-number-road-deaths-netherlands-determined
NA
Registration rate and available tables
The completeness of a source is expressed in the reporting rate: the reported number devided by the true number (as percentage).
The reporting rate is especially low for slighter accindents (just propery damage or slight injuries), for single accidents and for accidents where no motor vehicle is involved.

Sometimes accidents involving elderly people in traffic are wronlgy classified as an illness. If a person involved dies from injury obtained in the crash, this meets the definition of a road traffic accident.
There is no reason to assume that the type of road plays a role in the completeness of the reporting of fatal road cashes.
However the type of vehicles that is regularly used on the type of road in question does indirectely ensure that the  completeness differs per road type.
NA
The reporting rate is available by the following chacteristics: Month (Maand), Weekday (Weekdag), Time (Tijdstip), Region (Provincie), Transport mode (Vervoerswijze), Age (Leeftijd) , Sex (Geslacht).
NA

In the years 2012 -2016, BRON is over complete because since 2012 there is no feedback between CBS and IenW.
Some fatalities in BRON have another cause of death in the CBS data, for example suicide.
At case level CBS is not allowed to pinpoint these cases (Low on statistic, GDPR).
See also the report Road death registration in the Netherlands; Comparing the different source files (Registraties van verkeersdoden Nederland) (Bos et al., 2023)
https://swov.nl/nl/publicatie/registraties-van-verkeersdoden-nederland
In recent years there is some cleaning of BRON and over completeness has decreased.
NA

Also by differences of characteristics of overlapping cases, it may occur that the reporting rate of a certain group exceeds 100%, for example when the transport mode is slighly different in either source.
